results.title: Changing religion
results.brief_description:
In response to a dwindling population, the Snowy Rovers and Orbost Football Clubs were driven to merge into the Orbost Snowy Rovers. This is a story of small town trauma and redemption.

Thank you to Peter Jenkins, Edna Towns, Rita Baker, Gary Squires, and Glen Davie. Archival video and still images reproduced courtesy of Orbost Snowy Rovers Football Club and “The Snowy River Mail”.

TRANSCRIPT

[INTERPOSING VOICES] PETER JENKINS: I think from background— well, the Snowy Rovers have always been very much a working-class team. A lot of the guys worked out in the bush, worked in the mills, you know, that line of work, physical hard, physical work, sort of went and played at the Snowy Rovers, whereas the bank people, the accountants and schoolteachers, all tended to come to the Orbost footy club. And it was pretty full-on rivalry.

[MEN SHOUTING]

[WHISTLE BLOWS]

EDNA TOWNS: Friday nights, I think you would have found that Rovers went up to the top hotel and the Orbost boys went down to the bottom hotel. You probably went to one butcher if he was a member of the Rovers, or a member of the Orbost, say, you went to him.

But it was really one eyed football, wasn’t it? But then once football was over, we were all friends again, because we all live in the same town, after all, don’t we? And we all have to live here.

[MEN SHOUTING]

RITA BAKER: Saturdays, your friends became your enemies.

EDNA TOWNS: Yes.

RITA BAKER: And the barracking at the football, Orbost used to be down one end, and the Rovers would be at the other end of the ground, and never the twain should meet. Otherwise it was on.

[HORNS HONKING]

EDNA TOWNS: They started to talk about amalgamation. Some agreed. Some didn’t. At first, I was against it, because you don’t like giving up your main team. But eventually we had to, because we knew if we didn’t join, we wouldn’t have a team.

Mainly because young ones were going away for employment, going to college, university, and getting jobs. There was no jobs here. Everything was closing down in the town. So that’s why we sort of had to join up .

PETER JENKINS: Prior to the merger, the only times both clubs had full numbers was when we were playing each other. We would go away and play advanced, and kids would end up playing thirds. Under-17s and them would play reserves. And there’d be reserves players played reserves, and then played seniors, because you really struggled. And you know, it was becoming quite embarrassing.

EDNA TOWNS: A little bit like a religion. You know, you change your religion, more or less, when you’re closing down one club and going to something different. And that’s how it felt. And probably Rita felt the same. You know, you’re losing all those years that you were with one club.

It was hard at first. It was hard for me to go down into the Orbost sheds. But we’ve got over that.

[MEN SHOUTING]

-We just sort of assembled down at the club rooms on a Saturday morning, and we’re given a choice of picking out our new shirt.

-T-shirt.

-T-shirt with the new emblem and that on.

[APPLAUSE]

EDNA TOWNS: We walked out arm in arm, and they took our photos, and everybody cheered us, said we’d done the right thing. And I thought, well, you know, everything must be going to be all right.

[LAUGHTER]

PETER JENKINS: All the mates that used to play against each other are all starting to come back and actually playing together, and they’re loving it. From a playing perspective, things are really positive. And I’d love to be part of the first part of success here, and I’m hoping that comes sooner rather than later.

results.title: [Stelarc: Stretched Skin No.4 Munich 1977]
results.brief_description:
This video footage is of a suspension performance entitled “Event for Stretched Skin No. 4” that took place at the Art Academy in Munich, Germany on 8 August 1977.

As the name suggests, this was Stelarc’s fourth suspension performance, in which the artist’s body is suspended in space by a series of hooks inserted into the skin. The artist began performing these durational performances in Japan in 1976; this was his first international performance.

In the video, we see the hooks being pierced into the skin across the back and front of the body. The body is then suspended upside down from a sculptural structure made out of logs of wood. The body hangs with arms outstretched in front of the windows of the Art Academy, showing Munich in the background. The performance is observed by a team of assistants, photographers and a small audience.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: [Stelarc: Event for Modified Man 1976]
results.brief_description:
This video is documentation of a performance entitled “Modulate / Meditate: Event for Modified Man” held at Tamura Gallery in Tokyo, Japan, from 26 January to 1 February 1976.

In this durational performance, Stelarc has hooks inserted into his back and sews first his lips and then his eyelids closed with a needle and thread. In the gallery are TV monitors including one showing an X-ray of his own body. Standing in the centre of the gallery with the hooks attached to the wall behind him, the artist captures the sounds of his own body – heartbeat, breath and blood rushing – which are then amplified throughout the space. In the latter part of the video, the participation of the body comes to an end: the artist removes the stitches from his eyelids and mouth and the hooks are removed.

This performance was originally filmed on 1/2 inch videotape.

results.title: Weevils mean business
results.creator_credit: AWB Limited and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The problem of weevil infestation in bulk wheat storage and its control in Australia. Weevils and other insect pests in grain are a potential danger to the well-being of Australian wheatgrowers. Shows the Board’s suggested methods of insect control on the farm and traces the story of Australian wheat from the farm to its consumption overseas.

results.title: Every Inch Australian
results.creator_credit: Roland Litchfield, Litchfield Films and ACTIL
results.brief_description: Gives a complete picture of processes used in the manufacture of cotton sheeting at the Actil plant at Woodville, South Australia. Emphasis is placed on the scientific control and checking of all production processes from the arrival of bales of raw cotton to the final packing of Actil products and their despatch to all parts of Australia.

results.title: Gel
results.creator_credit: Ralph Henderson, Eric White and Films Sagittaire
results.brief_description: Produced for the Davis Gelatine company, the film uses a domestic science student to outline some of the properties and uses of gelatine. Various examples of modern gelatine cookery are also shown.

results.title: The Melbourne Concert Hall
results.creator_credit: David Greig, David Morgan, The Victorian Arts Centre and Kestrel Films (Australia)
results.brief_description: Interviews with architects, administrators, interior designers, construction workers and others associated with the construction of the Melbourne Concert Hall. Artists who have performed at the venue also give their opinion of hall. Those interviewed include: Roy Ground, Neil Haysom, Theodore Schultz, Ken Myer, John Truscott and Kenny Christophers. Shows segments from performances by Jackie Love, Cleo Laine, Sylvio Gualdo, Karen Knowles, London Early Music Group, Mondo Rock, the guitarist John Williams, Brian May’s Melbourne Showband and conductors Piero Gamba, Patrick Thomas and John Hopkins. Views of Melbourne’s skyline capture the Gas and Fuel buildings that were demolished to accommodate Federation Square.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, David Morgan, The Victorian Arts Centre and Kestrel Films (Australia)

results.title: Kimberley: Wandjina country
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Australian wilderness series”.
Part three of a series of six documentaries that examine the wilderness areas of Australia. Belinda Wright and Stanley Breeden are naturalists and photographers who work for the National Geographic Society. As they become fascinated with the “Wandjina” rock paintings, the viewer also gains some insight into the deep, spiritual relationship the Aboriginal people have with the land. A Teacher’s guide accompanies the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Morgan, John Richardson and Kestrel Film Productions

results.title: [Remix: ACMI Collection]
results.brief_description:
“Some of the thousands of stories in our collection.” This playful short film set to music, is a tribute to the gems in the ACMI Collection. A remix of home movies and short works from the collection featuring children and families, fashion models, road trips, city streets and swimming pools.

ACMI gratefully acknowledge the following donors and creators in the compilation of this work: Boort Historical Society, Tony Agapitos, Jenny & Owen Peake, John Richardson, Karen Wootton, Daniel Scharf, Frank & John Straford, Ivan Gaal and The Gadsden Family.
